content.raw:
I've run with this branch applied on top of default for about an hour, mostly working on task2.

It seems to work fine.  The feet seem shaky after a re-harness; I find it important to square them, and the controller seems to like to dip low at least once in the first few steps, but it broadly seems to work.

Sure is nice not to have to restart when I accidentally walk into the trailer... :-)
content.html:
I've run with this branch applied on top of default for about an hour, mostly working on task2.

It seems to work fine. The feet seem shaky after a re-harness; I find it important to square them, and the controller seems to like to dip low at least once in the first few steps, but it broadly seems to work.

Sure is nice not to have to restart when I accidentally walk into the trailer... :-)

content.raw: Thanks for trying this out! I'll see if I get the feet to be more stable.
content.html: Thanks for trying this out! I'll see if I get the feet to be more stable.

content.raw: Increased the threshold to consider the robot standing on f6f568d. It takes a bit longer, but the robot looks more stable right after detaching.
content.html: Increased the threshold to consider the robot standing on f6f568d. It takes a bit longer, but the robot looks more stable right after detaching.

content.raw:
I tried this out a bit, but I'm having a bit of a problem.  I built this code, then launched with:

`$ roslaunch srcsim finals.launch final_number:=4 gui:=true`

It then launched everything, and after a few seconds, it seemed to drop Val from a pretty good height, and the controller couldn't recover.  unique.launch seemed to do the same thing.  As a check, I went back to default, and launched with init:=true, and things worked OK there.  I'm going to review the code, but we should look into this.
content.html:
I tried this out a bit, but I'm having a bit of a problem. I built this code, then launched with:

$ roslaunch srcsim finals.launch final_number:=4 gui:=true

It then launched everything, and after a few seconds, it seemed to drop Val from a pretty good height, and the controller couldn't recover. unique.launch seemed to do the same thing. As a check, I went back to default, and launched with init:=true, and things worked OK there. I'm going to review the code, but we should look into this.

content.raw:
Ah sorry @clalancette , I mentioned on one of the comments that I've only generated unique.world for now while it's being reviewed, and will generate all the finals worlds once this is approved. I should have mentioned that on the top.

Also, I forgot to mention, but you should use [this deb](#!/osrf/srcsim/issues/170/integrate-re-harness-into-checkpoint#comment-36910009) for `val_description`.

Ah sorry @clalancette , I mentioned on one of the comments that I've only generated unique.world for now while it's being reviewed, and will generate all the finals worlds once this is approved. I should have mentioned that on the top.

content.raw: This lock protects the internals of the object from being modified simultaneously between Start() and Update() (good!).  Do we also need the mutex on some of the other methods in here, like Skip()?  How about the subclasses?
content.html: This lock protects the internals of the object from being modified simultaneously between Start() and Update() (good!). Do we also need the mutex on some of the other methods in here, like Skip()? How about the subclasses?

content.raw:
The lock was protecting `this->current`, to make sure it doesn't change while we're checking it. That variable wasn't being used by the derived classes, so I made it private in 78b19fe.

We could add a mutex to Skip(), but it would need to be a recursive mutex, since both Start and Update call that.
content.html:
The lock was protecting this->current, to make sure it doesn't change while we're checking it. That variable wasn't being used by the derived classes, so I made it private in 78b19fe.

We could add a mutex to Skip(), but it would need to be a recursive mutex, since both Start and Update call that.

content.raw: If you are satisfied that this is enough protection, I'm fine with that.  I was just double-checking (threading, you know?) :).
content.html: If you are satisfied that this is enough protection, I'm fine with that. I was just double-checking (threading, you know?) :).

content.raw: Overall, the code looks pretty good; nothing glaring stands out to me.  If we fix the nits, and figure out why my setup isn't working, I think this will be set.
content.html: Overall, the code looks pretty good; nothing glaring stands out to me. If we fix the nits, and figure out why my setup isn't working, I think this will be set.
